channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Is Denounced at U.N. Over Nuclear Threat and Alleged War Crimes
item.description: A day after Putin escalated the war, Russian men were receiving draft papers and some were fleeing the country. The war’s biggest prisoner exchange prompted jubilation in Ukraine, but some backlash in Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Protests in Iran
item.description: Dozens of cities have been embroiled in protests that were prompted by a young woman’s death in custody but have escalated amid anger over religious rules and a rock-bottom economy.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Protesters in the streets of Tehran on Wednesday. The protests have grown to encapsulate a wide range of grievances against the government.

item.title: 2 Michael Jackson Impersonators Look Identical. The Resemblance Ends There.
item.description: Two imitators of the King of Pop in Buenos Aires offer a study in contrasts, reflective of Argentina’s deep economic divide. One man financed 13 surgeries, while the other draws on his sideburns.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Anita Pouchard Serra
item.media:description: Leo Blanco is a Michael Jackson impersonator in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

item.title: Biden Paints Russia as a Threat to the World in U.N. Speech
item.description: President Biden portrayed Russia as the chief threat to global peace and renewed warnings that “a nuclear war cannot be won.”
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: President Biden told the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Wednesday that the West “will stand in solidarity against Russia’s aggression.”

item.title: As Russia Retreats, a Question Lingers: Who Counts as a Collaborator?
item.description: In towns reclaimed from Russian occupation, Ukrainian officials are working to identify — and punish — those who helped the enemy. It’s dividing some communities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Water Problems in Syria Give Rise to Deadly Cholera Outbreak
item.description: The highly contagious disease has spread quickly in the country’s north, where millions of people displaced by a decade-long war are living, and many rely on untreated water from rivers containing raw sewage.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Jane Arraf
item.media:description: A child diagnosed with cholera is treated at a hospital in Syria's Deir al-Zour province.

item.title: Catholics Outnumber Protestants in Northern Ireland for the First Time
item.description: Newly released census results may fuel calls for a referendum on uniting Ireland, experts say, but not right away.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sinn Féin campaign posters and a Republican mural on Falls Road, a Catholic stronghold in Belfast, earlier this year.

item.title: Russian Men, Fearing Ukraine Draft, Seek Refuge Abroad
item.description: Vladimir V. Putin’s new military call-up has sent young men who don’t want to fight in Ukraine heading to the borders.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Istanbul International Airport. With the government replenishing its military in Ukraine, some Russian men have headed for the borders.

item.title: In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge Trials Come to an End
item.description: The last surviving leader of the regime that killed 1.7 million Cambodians lost his appeal on Thursday. Some victims think the long, expensive tribunal was a hollow exercise.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nhet Sok Heng/Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Khieu Samphan, 91, the last surviving Khmer Rouge leader, during his hearing at the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia in Phnom Penh on Thursday.

item.title: Putin Raises Stakes in the War, With Direct Challenge to the West
item.description: The Russian leader announced a call-up of troops and hinted at using nuclear weapons, accusing the West of trying to “destroy our country” and vowing that Russia would defend itself.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A recruitment poster for the Russian military in Saint Petersburg this week.

item.title: North Korea Denies U.S. Claims of Arms Sales to Russia
item.description: Pyongyang accused the United States of spreading “reckless” rumors, but added that it had the right to build and export arms.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, in Vladivostok, Russia, in 2019.

item.title: Vladimir Putin When Cornered Is More Dangerous Than Ever
item.description: In a major speech, he recast the war in Ukraine and made clear it could spread.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Calling up 300,000 reservists, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia tacitly acknowledged both Russia’s struggles and the existence of a unified Ukraine.

item.title: How ‘Lord of the Rings’ Inspires Italy’s Giorgia Meloni
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, the nationalist politician who is the front-runner to become prime minister, sees “The Lord of the Rings” as not just a series of novels, but also a sacred text.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: As a youth activist, Giorgia Meloni revered “The Lord of the Rings” and other works by the British writer J.R.R. Tolkien.

item.title: Victims Recall Life in the Philippines Under Marcos’s Martial Law
item.description: Ferdinand E. Marcos placed the country under military rule 50 years ago this week. With his son now in power, those who lived through those dark days fear their stories will be lost.
item.dc:creator: Jes Aznar and Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Men Flee Russian Conscription
item.description: Plus Japan props up the yen and Cambodia concludes its Khmer Rouge trials.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A billboard in St. Petersburg promoting military service.

item.title: Bill to Grant Afghan Evacuees a Path to Residency Hits Snags
item.description: The White House and members of both parties had hoped to attach the legislation to a must-pass spending bill this month. But some Republicans have raised security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Kennedy, a veteran who served in Afghanistan, traveled from Maine to the Capitol to demonstrate in favor of the Afghan Adjustment Act.

item.title: World Bank Leader, Accused of Climate Denial, Offers a New Response
item.description: David Malpass touched off a furor, including calls for his removal, when he refused to acknowledge that fossil fuels are warming the planet.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: David Malpass was nominated to lead the World Bank in 2019 by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Are Freed. Joy Ripples Across the Country.
item.description: After the largest prisoner exchange of the war, Ukrainians celebrated while anger coursed through the ranks of Russian mercenaries and military bloggers.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Azov battalion officers, including the commander, Denys Prokopenko, middle, spoke after being released in a prisoner exchange between Russia and Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: Waves of Russian Men Flee, Fearing Call-Up to Fight in Ukraine
item.description: Since the announcement of a new troop mobilization, civilians have realized they could not count on staying out of their country’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Passengers at Moscow’s Domodedovo airport in March.

item.title: Andy Byford, Ex-M.T.A. Leader, Steps Down as London Transport Commissioner
item.description: Mr. Byford, who was revered as “Train Daddy” during his tenure as the chief of the New York City subway, said he would move back to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Andy Byford, center left, the commissioner of Transport for London, and Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, tour a station on the newly opened Elizabeth line in May.

item.title: Bad to Worse for Russia
item.description: Vladimir Putin’s call-up of more troops highlights Russia’s continuing struggles in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian solders riding in Kupiansk, Ukraine.

item.title: Europe’s Shrinking Waterways Reveal Treasures, and Experts Are Worried
item.description: Drought combined with extreme heat this summer have painted a dramatic picture of Europe’s drying rivers and reservoirs.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: The underwater ruins of the village of Aceredo emerged due to the low water level of the Lindoso reservoir in northwestern Spain.

item.title: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Putin Ally, Is Released in Russia-Ukraine Prisoner Swap
item.description: The Ukrainian politician and oligarch had acted as the Kremlin’s primary agent of influence in Ukraine for years.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Viktor Medvedchuk leaving a court hearing in Kyiv in 2021.

item.title: In India, Debunking Fake News and Running Into the Authorities
item.description: Alt News, an independent website, has emerged as a leading debunker of misinformation in the nation, but highlighting hate speech against minorities has put it on a collision course with the government.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alt News staff members in Ahmedabad, India. The site has debunked hundreds of cases of bogus information in India.

item.title: Lavrov Blasts Zelensky and Ukraine at UN Security Council Meeting
item.description: Insults, accusations and talk of war crimes and nuclear holocaust dominated the world’s premier diplomatic stage on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council met in New York on Thursday to discuss allegations of human rights violations and war crimes in Ukraine.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A warning from Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Russian Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Calling up 300,000 reservists, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia tacitly acknowledged both Russia’s struggles and the existence of a unified Ukraine.

item.title: Truss Pledges to Support Ukraine in Speech at U.N. General Assembly
item.description: The prime minister of Britain also restated a promise to raise Britain’s spending on defense to 3 percent of G.D.P. by 2030, a commitment long urged by the United States,.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain with Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine in New York on Tuesday. Ms. Truss pledged strong support for Ukraine.

item.title: In U.N. General Assembly Address, Zelensky Says, ‘Russia Should Pay for This War’
item.description: “A crime has been committed against Ukraine, and we demand just punishment,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said in a recorded speech to the U.N. General Assembly.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a recorded speech delivered to the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine criticized countries that have tried to avoid antagonizing Russia.

item.title: Russia releases 215 fighters, including Mariupol commanders, in a prisoner exchange.
item.description: The exchange, the war’s largest, included Viktor Medvechuk, a Ukrainian oligarch and close friend of the Russian president.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz

item.title: Washington Pays Tribute to a Different Type of Leader
item.description: Politicians and diplomats, including Vice President Kamala Harris, paid their respects to Queen Elizabeth II at a memorial service in Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris; her husband, Doug Emhoff; Speaker Nancy Pelosi; and Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, attending a service commemorating Queen Elizabeth II at the National Cathedral on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia’s ‘Partial Mobilization’
item.description: Plus protests in Iran intensify and New York State sues Donald Trump for fraud.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: President Joe Biden delivered remarks before the 77th Session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York, New York, Wednesday.

item.title: Senate Ratifies Kigali Amendment, the Global Pact to Curb Hydrofluorocarbons
item.description: In a bipartisan vote, lawmakers voted to join an international agreement to phase out the hydrofluorocarbons commonly found in refrigerators and air-conditioners.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.category: Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Air-conditioners in New Delhi in April. The Kigali Amendment of 2016 aims to sharply reduce the use of planet-warming refrigerants known as hydrofluorocarbons.

item.title: William Ruto Warns About Climate Change at U.N. General Assembly
item.description: “We cannot afford to waste another moment debating the merits of doing something vis a vis doing nothing,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenya’s newly elected president, William Ruto, addressing world leaders at the 77th session of the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: At Least 1,252 People Are Detained in Protests in Russia
item.description: Protesters show their disapproval of the policy announced by President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday morning that would press 300,000 people into military service.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Police officers detaining a man after calls to protest against the call-up of reservists, in Moscow, on Wednesday. At least 1,312 people were detained, according to the human rights watchdog OVD-Info.

item.title: For Churches, Abortion Politics Is a Double-Edged Sword
item.description: Ireland and Poland went in entirely opposite directions on abortion. Why?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Supporters celebrate at Dublin Castle after a constitutional amendment legalizing abortion passed in 2018.

item.title: 10 Prisoners, Including Americans, Have Been Released in a Russia-Ukraine Exchange
item.description: Alex Drueke, a former U.S. Army staff sergeant who served two tours in Iraq, and Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh, a former U.S. Marine, were released.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Jeronimo Nisa/The Decatur Daily, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Andy Tai Ngoc Huynh in Hartselle, Ala., in April.

item.title: President Raisi Addresses U.N. General Assembly Amid Protests in Iran
item.description: “We are the defenders of a fight against injustice,” President Ebrahim Raisi told the U.N. General Assembly as his government faces widespread protests over the rights of women.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran made his first appearance at the United Nations headquarters in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Criticizes Iran and China on Human Rights and Security Issues
item.description: President Biden said that Washington “will be unabashed in promoting” a vision of a free world.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We will not allow Iran to acquire a nuclear weapon,” President Biden said, adding, “I continue to believe diplomacy is the best way to achieve this outcome.”

item.title: One-Way Flights From Russia Are Selling Out or Skyrocketing in Price
item.description: Some Russians rushed to buy airfare after President Vladimir V. Putin ordered up reservists to bolster the country’s military in Ukraine. Tickets to some visa-free destinations are sold out for several days.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Tickets to some of the most popular visa-free destinations out of Moscow are either sold out or are skyrocketing in price.

item.title: Germany’s chancellor calls Putin ‘desperate.’
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany spoke to the United Nations General Assembly in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: John Train, Paris Review Co-Founder and Cold War Operative, Dies at 94
item.description: His career, ranging from literature to finance to war, and from France to Afghanistan, seemed to cover every interest and issue of his exalted social class.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Protests in Iran Intensify Over the Death of Mahsa Amini in Custody
item.description: Unrest has spread to dozens of cities, with at least seven people killed, according to witnesses, rights groups and video posted on social media.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters in the streets of Tehran on Wednesday. The protests have grown to encapsulate a wide range of grievances against the government.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Story of Russia’ by Orlando Figes
item.description: In a new book, the historian Orlando Figes argues that the war on Ukraine is only the latest instance of a nation twisting the past to justify its future.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Feifer
item.media:description: The 2016 unveiling of a Moscow monument to Grand Prince Vladimir, who is credited with bringing Orthodox Christianity to what became Russia.

item.title: E.U. countries ask the U.N to appoint a monitor to assess human rights violations in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shop at army games in the Moscow region in August.

item.title: The Theater at War
item.description: In shows like “The Burnt City,” the chaos of war meets the curated artifice of performance, our critic writes. But “Oresteia” took a different view, and the audience was better for it.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: German Far-Right Politicians Cancel Trip to Russian-Occupied Part of Donbas
item.description: The planned visit by state politicians of the Alternative for Germany party was controversial, with critics saying it would chip away at national unity over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Volunteers helping to evacuate civilians from Bakhmut, a Ukrainian-controlled city in Donbas that has endured relentless Russian shelling.

item.title: Iran’s President Speaks at U.N. as Protests Rock His Nation
item.description: The Iranian president, who came to power last year, will address the assembly amid large demonstrations at home and international pressure to revive the Iran nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran at a news conference in Tehran last month.

item.title: China offers a muted response to Putin’s announcement as it tries to maintain ties to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Sergei Bobylyov/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse —Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russian, left, and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, meeting in Uzbekistan last week.

item.title: French Left Lawmaker Admits Slapping Wife, and Party Leader Defends Him
item.description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the leader of the leftist France Unbowed party, expressed “trust” and “affection” for Adrien Quatennens, setting off a firestorm.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Adrien Quatennens, shown last month speaking in the National Assembly in Paris, said he would step down from his role as a top coordinator for the France Unbowed party.
